title: Personal data, privacy, and the (sematic) web

author: Jennifer Golbeck, University of Maryland University College (UMUC)

segmentation: Hi everybody, yes I'm gonna go back and from the University of Maryland they did my PhD there change department's stuck around and now they're keeping me permanently 'cause I'm a full professor, so they can't get rid of me no matter what I do, which is pretty awesome at this point.

I wanted to study.

You know, we weren't even really calling it social media then, but social networks and how people can trust one another and so basically the solution that I had, is that I was going to have to build a social network because like there was no API like you couldn't use data from any of these social networks.
And so I built a couple.
I built one that I think I called trust net.
I couldn't even find anything about it, but it was just basically you sign up and you could list your friends and then you could rate how much you trust them.
This is what you did on social networks back in the days that the 10 Myspace users in the room know this.
But even like.
Early Facebook users.
There was no such thing as a status update.
You couldn't post pictures like what you did is maintain a profile.
You put a picture of yourself up there and then there was kind of a form you'd fill in with, like your name and where you went to school and your hobbies and list your friends and that was it.
And that was a huge thing because before that you had to basically be able to do HTML and have a web host an FTP and put your files online.
If you wanted a profile and people would then somehow have to find it, which was very much not good then.

So having one place where anyone could make a profile was a big deal in what you did on social media was spend a lot of time working on your profile page and then looking at your friend's profile pages and we would list stuff about people.
So Myspace had like you could list your top friends if you got mad at somebody to kick him off your top list of friends.
So it seemed like a thing people would do is rate how much they trust their friends.
It turns out this was not a thing that we do but it was a thing that people were willing to do that.
And so I made this first network trust net.
And you know, kind of bullied a bunch of people I knew into joining and I was out putting a representation of that network in RDF using FOAF.
I was a big fan of folks.
We had some folk workshops that I thought it was great and so there was a little RDF file for every user that had their profile information.
All their friends and then I had augmented the FOAF ontology with the trust ontology and it had just like a one to 10 rating.
I think how much you trust people.
This seems like a reasonable idea, but what I did was get a bunch of my grad student friends and then also bunch faculty members at Maryland.
They were all people who joined this.
And the guy in the office next to me started looking at the RDF an.
He's like my advisor gave me a 3 out of 10.
That was all public right?
You'd rated how much he trusted people and they put out the RDF.
He was super upset about this and I was like oh I have just made this huge mistake right?

I've taken this potentially really sensitive information and even though I said it's going to be out there on the public web, I don't think his advisor knew that he'd be able to see that three and people got really upset in it.
It started me thinking about this idea of privacy and like how do we work with that on the semantic web?
How do we have this data that we can interchange that everybody can access?
We went on to later build another network called Film Trust which was like movie Recommendation system.
We could rate how much you trusted people.
That was a little bit less sensitive 'cause you don't get super offended if someone doesn't trust your taste in movies.

Doing some semantic web stuff with this, I want to be sharing this, but there's maybe some issues that come with that.
So let's pick something like movies that aren't super sensitive at the same time.
So kind of back in 2005 there was this website that came out called Plink, which I think stood for people link it was.
I don't even know who made it, but it was some semantic web aficionado and they said we're going to find all the folks we can find online.
Basically all this RDF about people and we're just going to aggregate it together and then we'll make a profile page for everybody.
It's like a social network, but you don't have to make your own page.

We're just going to take data about you from other places, and that's sort of OK. 'cause like how many people had FOAF data about them out there, it was like the Semantic Web grad students basically, right?
Like making ourselves some folk, except there was some semantic web person who got to work on.
I don't know if it was Obama's but somebody's election campaign in the 2004 election cycle, and so back then.

And still sort of they would have this thing where it's like, hey, if you're interested in so and so's campaign, invite your friends to the website so you put in your address so they could send an email from you and you put in your friend's address and it would send a message to your friend from you that says hey come check out so and so's campaign page.
And for every person who did that they made a little photo file that said these two people are friends with their email addresses in it.
Link sucked that up 'cause it was all just out there on the web and so suddenly 10s of thousands of people who didn't know anything about the semantic web were finding themselves and their friends.

Profile now on this site that ultimately got shut down because of that backlash and so we have a couple of these instances that actually sound like sort of modern privacy issues on social media coming out before Facebook even existed in these really early days where we were trying to think about exchanging this data and it was interesting to me to think about how that kind of set the context for these challenges that we faced over and over going forward.

Not just among my people on Mechanical Turk, kind of, with a more general population.
There tends to be a shift away from the privacy, unconcerned, which I think is fair.

Or aware of what's going on with their data.

So when I talk about privacy and I'm talking specifically here about personal data that you can expand this out into other contexts if you want, I get some pushback and I had, I think that one exchange that.
That really stuck with me on this.

It's available to us.
There's nothing that you can do about it anymore, so like just get over it.
Like if you're talking about that, you just don't understand the way that the world is right.
One of these dismissive answers.
This makes me very angry when people say stuff like that because I think that he and the large number of people who spew that line fundamentally misunderstand what privacy is.
Privacy is not keeping something totally secret, right?
I'm going to keep this to myself.
I'm not going to tell everyone like there are those things, but that's not what privacy means.
Privacy is that I determine what information I'm going to share with what people in what context, at what time, and hopefully what they're going to do with it.
So I'm a tell you about a medical condition that I have.
That doesn't mean I want the whole world to know it.
It doesn't mean I'm going to put it up on a public website, but I may say, hey, you know you're my friend.
I want to talk to you about this.
I'm going to disclose this information to you.
This is where it's OK to use.
Please don't tell anybody, right?
That's privacy.
It's not 100% secret, but it's privacy.
So ultimately privacy is an issue of consent.
Do I consent to you having this information about me and using it in this way?

That's ultimately what it is, and if you take those lines from Silicon Valley where we get dismissed about privacy concerns and just plug in the word consent in place of privacy, it both reduces their argument and highlights a whole lot of other problems, right?
What was his line?
Consent is stupid, like just get over it.
We can take whatever we want from you anytime we want it.
So why are you so worried about consent?
Just let us have what we want and stop pretending like you have a right to control this right?
That sounds really bad.
I hope that sounds really bad to all of you.
That's what it sounds like to me when they make these arguments about privacy that essentially we can take whatever he wants, so just get over it and let us do it.
If you say that about consent, it sounds bad, and so I like to use this as a device when I end up in these debates with people to say we can kind of agree that this is what privacy is.
It's this consent element over our information.
So just plug in consent every place that you say privacy and see if you dismiss it as readily.
And if you do, that's not a person that you want to spend much time with.
And if you don't, it means you need to rethink how you're doing things.
And so I want that idea to underlie what we're going to talk about here.
That privacy and consent are fundamentally the same thing.
Or rather, that privacy is consent.
If you take away that consent element, you're essentially taking away the heart of what is privacy?

So what that tells us is that this video, which was essentially kind of privacy related entertainment, is as if not more effective than reading that boring text in 90 seconds at telling people how their data is being shared.

And I think this highlights a big component of the problem that I want to highlight, which is that people don't understand how much of their data is getting collected, and you know, we see it in the news, but I talk.
I mean, I talk every week at least once to an audience of this size or bigger about these issues.

All these like vast amounts of data that are being collected and potentially shared like people really don't understand the scope of that.
And I think that there's a huge space of research both on like how to better educate people about that.
And how to increase the transparency around that?
There's a real battle to fight there against some elements of industry, not all but some elements of industry don't want people to understand this because people are going to get upset about it.
But I think this is an important component of the whole privacy landscape.
Beyond that, then I wanted to focus on this idea of consent and comfort with data being shared.

And so we ran a big study on Mechanical Turk and we gave people a whole bunch of data that's commonly used in personalization and social media that shared with apps and we asked them if you found out that this data about you is being used by someone like Amazon or a website that was like personalizing your experience with it, would you feel like that's not at all a privacy violation or pretty serious violation?

You know, in the kind of mid 2000s on what are the issues that come up with this, and I think the semantic web has a real opportunity, especially in the space of transparency, making it clear what data is used in what data is being shared, because we know that people are underestimating that and also highlighting the provenance of data.
So if I have this data in front of me, where did that come from?

There's great opportunities and I spent a couple years playing in this space and I don't think I contributed meaningfully, but I was really fascinated by this idea of using the semantic web for provenance of data to kind of track where it came from.
Where did it go to?
You know, there's good stuff that the bones to do that are here in the community, and I think finding a way to deploy that at a scale wherever possible with this kind of social data.
Is a real opportunity to take this kind of technology?
And processing ability that we have and we know the semantic web community has and then bring it into this problem, which is, I think, one of the biggest problems on the web for the average user.
At this point we all have huge amounts of data out there.
We don't know where it comes from.
We don't know where it's going to.
Our research has shown that people want to know this is a critical component of people having trust in these sites that they're using in the apps that they're using.
And so even if you know, I don't think we're going to convince.

Are doing a good job on.

So I mentioned I talked to all of these different groups and a lot of them are really concerned about this so.
It was supposed to be talking to Realtors in Florida tomorrow they have hurricane and so I'm not talking to them tomorrow, but they're really concerned about this right?
Real Estate is an industry where trust in the person you're working with is really important.
I talked to lots of financial advisors and investment advisors.

This person.
What kind of things would be appealing to this person?

That's great.

We want to be able to do that for people, but if I find out that my financial advisor just took a bunch of data from some data brokers and then like use an app and stole some stuff off my phone and then without telling me they use that to make a profile of me that's influencing what they say, I wouldn't trust that person anymore.

Right, the semantic Web gives us an opportunity for them to create this record and representation about the provenance of that data, where it came from, what kind of operations they did on it, and to be really transparent, because I don't think all of this technology is bad, I don't think using this data is bad, but for them to say, hey, here's where all this data came from.

We have the ability to consent.
We've got all of these things that actually help enhance trust.
